{{also|morgen}} ==German== ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/ˈmɔrɡən/|[ˈmɔʁ-]|[ˈmɔɐ̯-]|[ˈmɔː-]|[-ɡən]|[-ɡŋ̍]}} * {{IPA|de|/mɔrŋ/|/mɔrjən/}} {{q|colloquial variants}} * {{audio|de|De-Morgen.ogg|audio}} ===Etymology 1=== From {{inh|de|gmh|morgen}}, from {{inh|de|goh|morgan}}, from {{inh|de|gem-pro|*murganaz}}, from {{der|de|ine-pro|*merkʷ-||to blink, twinkle}}. Compare {{cog|nds|Morgen}}, {{cog|nl|morgen}}, {{cog|fy|moarn}}, {{cog|en|morn}}, {{m|en|morrow}}, {{cog|da|morgen}}, {{cog|sv|morgon}}. ====Noun==== {{de-noun|m|Morgens|Morgen|pl2=Morgende}} # [[morning]] {{gloss|part of the day from dawn to noon}} # {{lb|de|agriculture|dated}} [[morgen]] {{gloss|measure of land equivalent to two acres}}; {{lb|de|informal}} [[acre]] {{q|when speaking vaguely}}, a [[quarter]] of a [[hectare]] {{q|specific}} # {{lb|de|archaic|poetic}} [[east]] {{gloss|direction of the rising sun at an equinox}} #: {{ux|de|gen '''Morgen''' gehen|walk in the direction where the sun rises}} =====Usage notes===== * The normal plural is unchanged {{m|de||Morgen}}. The dialectal plural {{m|de|Morgende}} is formed under the influence of {{m|de|Abende|t=evenings}}. It is rather common colloquially but hardly ever used in literary German. * {{m|de||Morgen}} includes the whole time of day between sunrise and noon, though the time roughly between 9 a.m. and noon is often specified as {{m|de|Vormittag}}. =====Declension===== {{de-decl-noun-m|s}} {{Template:list:times of day/de}} ====Synonyms==== * {{sense|morning}} {{l|de|Vormittag}} * {{sense|east}} {{gloss|the day after today}} # the [[future]] #: {{ux|de|Unser '''Morgen''' ist wichtiger als unser Heute.|Our '''future''' is more important than our present.}} {{topics|de|Times of day|Units of
